prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We configure the correlator with 4 SPW. One of them is centered at the requested transition while the others are situated for the sake of serendipity line detection. We used smoothing of 8 channels resulting in resolution of ~5 km/s, enough to properly resolve the 300 km/s wide line of NGC4945.

Emission is expected to be located in GMC complexes of ~5" extent. Thus we will be able to resolve this emission with our requested 1" resolution. Little extended emission is expected to be filtered out with the compact ALMA configurations so ACA is not requested.

Measured peak flux of this line with APEX is 133 mJy. From the unresolved maps of Cunningham et al. 2005 we estimate the emission not to be extended above 5" in individual 25 km/s channels. Thus in the case of uniformly distributed emission we would end up in peak fluxes of 5 mJy per beam. So in the worst case with a sensitivity of 1mJy per channel we would achive a S/N>5. However, usually the emission will be clumpier and on top of that the broad lines allow for smoothing still resolving the lines with several channels.

We configure the correlator with 4 SPW. One of them is centered at the requested transition while the others are situated for the sake of serendipity line detection. We used smoothing of 8 channels resulting in resolution of ~4 km/s, enough to properly resolve the 300 km/s wide line of NGC4945.

Emission is expected to be located in GMC complexes of ~5" extent. Thus we will be able to resolve this emission with our requested 1" resolution. Little extended emission is expected to be filtered out with the compact ALMA configurations so ACA is not requested.

Measured peak flux of this line with APEX is 210 mJy. From the unresolved maps of Cunningham et al. 2005 we estimate the emission not to be extended above 5" in individual 25 km/s channels. Thus in the case of uniformly distributed emission we would end up in peak fluxes of 8 mJy per beam. So in the worst case with a sensitivity of 1mJy per channel we would achive a S/N>8. However, usually the emission will be clumpier and on top of that the broad lines allow for smoothing still resolving the lines with several channels. In this line we go for an enhancen S/N (>8) compared to what we requested for the 222 GHz line (>5) in order to get a better disentangling from the blended SO transition.

We configure the correlator with 4 SPW. One of them is centered at the requested transition while the others are situated for the sake of serendipity line detection. We used smoothing of 8 channels resulting in resolution of ~4 km/s, enough to properly resolve the 300 km/s wide line of NGC4945.

Emission is expected to be located in GMC complexes of ~5" extent. Thus we will be able to resolve this emission with our requested 1" resolution. Little extended emission is expected to be filtered out with the compact ALMA configurations so ACA is not requested. We used smoothing of 8 channels resulting in resolution of ~4 km/s, enough to properly resolve the 300 km/s wide line of NGC4945.

From the unresolved maps of Cunningham et al. 2005 we estimate the emission not to be extended above 5" in individual 25 km/s channels. Peak emission in those maps is 340 mJy for the 3mm transition. The 265 GHz transition is expected to be at least a factor of 2 more intense or higher for excitation temperatures >10 K. Thus in the case of uniformly distributed emission we would end up in peak fluxes of >30 mJy per beam. Still we used a 1.5 mJy sensitivity which will provide an excellent S/N. Integration on source is already just 8 min, so increasing the sensitivity would have little impact on the ~30min total time requested.

We configure the correlator with 4 SPW. One of them is centered at the requested transition while the others are situated for the sake of serendipity line detection. We used smoothing of 8 channels resulting in resolution of ~4 km/s, enough to properly resolve the 300 km/s wide line of NGC4945.

Emission is expected to be located in GMC complexes of ~5" extent. Thus we will be able to resolve this emission with our requested 1" resolution. Little extended emission is expected to be filtered out with the compact ALMA configurations so ACA is not requested.

From the unresolved maps of Cunningham et al. 2005 we estimate the emission not to be extended above 5" in individual 25 km/s channels. Peak emission in those maps is 270 mJy. The 265 GHz transition is expected to be at least a factor of 2 more intense or higher for excitation temperatures >10 K. Thus in the case of uniformly distributed emission we would end up in peak fluxes of >20 mJy per beam. Still we used a 1.5 mJy sensitivity which will provide an excellent S/N. Integration on source is already just 8 min, so increasing the sensitivity would have little impact on the ~30min total time requested.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We have detected emission from two transitions of HCNH+ from a starburst galaxy using APEX telescope being the first detection of this molecule on extragalactic medium. ALMA has an enormous potential for accurate line identification due to its sensitivity as well as to his resolving capabilities. Moreover, we will be able to study the origin of this particularly intersting species. The most likely hypotheses that explains an unusually high HNC abundance in interstellar medium is that HCNH+ is the precursor of both HNC and HCN, and the dissociative recombination reaction with an electron is claimed to be the main process for the production of HNC and HCN. Only with ALMA we will be able to identify key extragalactic molecules related to the origin of very abundant molecules such as HNC and HCN.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
